skills.name: Describe the solution to a graphical inequality involving a single vertical line
Describe the solution to a graphical inequality involving a single diagonal line
Describe the solution to a graphical inequality involving a combination of vertical, horizontal and diagonal lines
Represent the solution to a graphical inequality involving a combination of vertical, horizontal and diagonal lines
Mark a point in the second quadrant of a 2D grid having been given its coordinates, where both values are integers

explanations.A: Not quite, is this the line y = -1? Checking the coordinates of the points on the line will help you to find the correct equation of the line.
explanations.B: The line drawn has equation ùë• = -1. Everything to the left is less than -1, so the shaded region is ùë• < -1.
explanations.C: Not quite, is this the line y = -1? Checking the coordinates of the points on the line will help you to find the correct equation of the line.
explanations.D: Not quite! This inequality matches the unshaded region. Pick a point in the shaded region, find its coordinates and compare to the equation of the line.

explanations.A: The line drawn has equation ùë• = 1. Everything to the right is greater than 1, so the shaded region is ùë• > 1.
explanations.B: Not quite, is this the line y = 1? Checking the coordinates of the points on the line will help you to find the correct equation of the line.
explanations.C: Not quite! This inequality matches the unshaded region. Pick a point in the shaded region, find its coordinates and compare to the equation of the line.
explanations.D: Not quite, is this the line y = 1? Checking the coordinates of the points on the line will help you to find the correct equation of the line.

explanations.A: If we pick any point within the region R, we can see that the x coordinate is greater than the y coordinate, and the x coordinate is less than -2.
explanations.B: Nearly! Pick a point in the region R and check if the y value greater than the x value.
explanations.C: Nearly! Pick a point in the region R and check if the x value greater than -2?
explanations.D: Not quite! The statement y > x means that the y coordinate is greater than the x coordinate. Pick a point within the region R and check if this the case. The statement x > -2 means that the x value is greater than -2 , check if this is case for your point.

explanations.A: Not quite! The statement y < x means that the y coordinate is less than the x coordinate. Pick a point within the region R and check if this is the case. The statement x < -2 means that the x value is less than -2, check if this is the case for your point.
explanations.B: Nearly! The statement x < -2 means that the x coordinate is less than -2. Pick a point within the region R and check if this is the case.
explanations.C: Nearly! The statement y < x means that the y coordinate is less than the x coordinate. Pick a point within the region R and check if this is the case.
explanations.D: If we pick any point within the region R, we can see that the x coordinate is less than the y coordinate, and the x coordinate is greater than -2.

explanations.A: Choose a coordinate in region A. x<0 means that the x coordinate should be less than 0 and y>0 means that the y coordinate should be greater than 0. Is this true for region A?
explanations.B: I think you are on the right track, but have misinterpreted your inequalities. x<0 means the x coordinates must be less than 0 and y>0 means the y coordinates must be greater than 0
explanations.C: Choose a coordinate in region C. x<0 means that the x coordinate should be less than 0 and y>0 means that the y coordinate should be greater than 0. Is this true for region C?
explanations.D: x<0 means that the x coordinates have to be less than 0. This is true in the regions to the left of the y axis. y>0 means that the y coordinates have to be greater than 0. This is true for the regions above the x axis. Therefore the region that satisfies both these inequalities is D.

explanations.A: Choose a coordinate in region A. x>0 means that the x coordinate should be greater than 0 and y<0 means that the y coordinate should be less than 0. Is this true for region A?
explanations.B: x>0 means that the x coordinates have to be greater than 0. This is true in the regions to the right of the y axis. y<0 means that the y coordinates have to be less than 0. This is true for the regions below the x axis. Therefore the region that satisfies both these inequalities is B.
explanations.C: Choose a coordinate in region C. x>0 means that the x coordinate should be greater than 0 and y<0 means that the y coordinate should be less than 0. Is this true for region C?
explanations.D: I think you are on the right track, but have misinterpreted your inequalities. x>0 means the x coordinates must be greater than 0 and y<0 means the y coordinates must be less than 0

explanations.A: Not quite! Check carefully to see if the equation of the dashed line is y = x or y = -x.
explanations.B: Not quite! Check carefully to see if the equation of the dashed line is y = x or y = -x. Then pick any point in the shaded region. Look at its x and y coordinates. Check to see if minus x is greater than y.
explanations.C: The equation of the dashed line is y = -x. Select a point in the shaded region, for example (2,1). We can see that the y coordinate is 1, and the minus of the x coordinate (-x) is -2. Since 1 is greater than -2, then y is greater than -x.
explanations.D: Nearly! Pick any point in the shaded region. Look at its x and y coordinates. Check to see if minus x is greater than y.

explanations.A: The equation of the solid line is y = x + 1. Select any point in the shaded region, for example (1, 3). We can see that the y coordinate is 3, and the x coordinate is 1, and therefore x + 1 = 1 + 1 = 2. Since 3 is greater than 2, then y is greater than or equal to x +1.
explanations.B: Nearly! Pick any point in the shaded region. Look at its x and y coordinates. Check to see if y is less than or equal to x + 1.
explanations.C: Not quite! Check carefully to see if the equation of the solid line is y = x + 1 or y = x - 1.
explanations.D: Not quite! Check carefully to see if the equation of the solid line is y = x + 1 or y = x - 1. The pick any point in the shaded region. Look at its x and y coordinates. Check to see if y is less than or equal to x + 1.

explanations.A: Not quite. This is the point of intersection as it is on both lines. It would count if our inequalities had the ‚â§ symbol rather than the < symbol and vice versa, but because the "or equal to" bit is missing it means we cannot include a point that is on the line.
explanations.B: The red line has the equation ùë• = 1 and we want the inequality ùë• > 1 so we need the region to the right of this. The purple line has equation y = ùë• + 2 and we want the inequality y < ùë• + 2 so we want the region below this line. So we need to find a coordinate that is to the right of the red line and below the purple line. This leaves coordinate (2,-1)
explanations.C: Not quite. Your coordinate satisfies the inequality x > 1, but does not satisfy y < x + 2
explanations.D: Not quite. Your coordinate satisfies the inequality y < x + 2, but does not satisfy x > 1

explanations.A: Not quite. Your coordinate satsifies the inequality 2 < x + y, but does not satisfy x < y
explanations.B: Not quite. This is the point of intersection as it is on both lines. It would count if our inequalities had the ‚â§ symbol rather than the < symbol, but because the "or equal to" bit is missing it means we cannot include a point that is on the line.
explanations.C: The red line has the equation 2 = x + y and we want the inequality 2 < x + y. We can rearrange this to get y > 2 - x which shows us we are interested in the region above this red line. The purple line has equation x = y and we want the inequality x < y so we want the region above this line (where y is greater than x). So we need to find a coordinate that is above both of these lines. This leaves coordinate (1,3)
explanations.D: Not quite. Your coordinate satisfies the inequality x < y, but does not satisfy 2 < x + y
